llm.i: Mark items as ✅ PASS, ❌ FAIL, ⚠️ PARTIAL, or N/A
Provide specific feedback for failed items
Focus on completeness of epic/story capture and MVP scope discipline

section.name: 1. Requirements Coverage in Epics/Stories
section.desc: Ensure all functional and non-functional requirements are captured in epics and stories
section.llm: Every requirement should map to at least one epic/story

subsection.name: 1.1 Functional Requirements Mapping
subsection.i: Every FR (Functional Requirement) is addressed by at least one epic or story
No orphaned functional requirements exist
Complex FRs are properly broken down across multiple stories
Requirements are testable through story acceptance criteria
Story acceptance criteria directly verify the linked requirements

subsection.name: 1.2 Non-Functional Requirements Integration
subsection.i: NFRs are integrated into relevant stories (not separate stories)
Performance requirements reflected in acceptance criteria
Security requirements embedded in authentication/data stories
Technical constraints addressed in Epic 1 foundation stories
Cross-cutting NFRs (logging, monitoring) flow through all epics

subsection.name: 1.3 User Journey Implementation
subsection.i: Primary user journey fully supported by epic sequence
Critical path from user journeys captured in stories
User journey decision points addressed in acceptance criteria
Secondary journeys covered or explicitly deferred
Journey failure scenarios handled in stories

section.name: 2. MVP Focus and Scope Discipline
section.desc: Verify the PRD maintains lean MVP scope and identifies bloat
section.llm: Challenge every feature - does it serve the core goals?

subsection.name: 2.1 Out of Scope Effectiveness
subsection.i: Out of scope section explicitly excludes tempting features
Exclusions have clear rationale tied to MVP goals
Nice-to-have features properly deferred
Complex integrations identified as post-MVP
Administrative features minimized for MVP

subsection.name: 2.2 Epic Scope Validation
subsection.i: Each epic delivers genuine user/business value when deployed
No epic is purely technical infrastructure without user value
Epic 1 combines foundation with minimal user-facing functionality
Later epics build incrementally on previous value
Epics can be deployed and provide value independently

subsection.name: 2.3 Story Necessity Check
subsection.i: Every story directly serves a functional requirement or core user journey
No gold-plating or perfectionist stories included
UI stories focus on functional needs, not visual polish
Data stories prioritize core entities over comprehensive schemas
Integration stories limited to essential external dependencies

section.name: 3. Epic and Story Structure Quality
section.desc: Ensure epics and stories are well-formed and executable
section.llm: Stories should be clear enough for implementation without additional clarification

subsection.name: 3.1 Epic Structure
subsection.i: Epic goals clearly state what value will be delivered
Epics are sequenced logically with clear dependencies
Epic 1 includes project setup AND initial functionality
Each epic represents a logical deployment unit
Epic boundaries align with natural project milestones

subsection.name: 3.2 Story Independence and Sizing
subsection.i: Stories are appropriately sized for a dumb dev agent to complete before exhausting context and hallucinating
Stories have NO dependency on future stories
Story prerequisites are clearly identified and justified
Stories provide complete vertical functionality slices
Stories are testable in isolation where possible

subsection.name: 3.3 Acceptance Criteria Completeness
subsection.i: Acceptance criteria define clear "done" conditions
ACs are specific enough to prevent implementation ambiguity
ACs include both happy path and key error scenarios
Backend/data stories specify local testability approaches
UI stories specify framework and component requirements

section.name: 4. Epic 1 Foundation Completeness
section.desc: Verify Epic 1 sets up everything needed for subsequent development
section.llm: Epic 1 should enable all later epics to build smoothly

subsection.name: 4.1 Project Infrastructure
subsection.i: Project scaffolding and directory structure established
Version control, CI/CD pipeline, and deployment setup included
Core framework and essential libraries integrated
Development environment fully configured
Testing framework and initial test structure established

subsection.name: 4.2 Core Services and Architecture
subsection.i: Database connection and core schema established
Authentication/authorization foundation implemented
API structure or UI framework properly initialized
Error handling and logging infrastructure in place
Basic health check or minimal user-facing functionality delivered

subsection.name: 4.3 Cross-Cutting Concerns
subsection.i: Monitoring and observability foundations established
Security fundamentals (HTTPS, basic auth) implemented
Configuration management approach established
Documentation structure and initial docs created
Deployment and environment promotion process working

section.name: 5. Technical Feasibility and Risk
section.desc: Identify technical risks and validate implementation approach
section.llm: Flag anything that might block or significantly delay development

subsection.name: 5.1 Technical Requirements Clarity
subsection.i: Technical assumptions are realistic and well-researched
Technology stack choices align with team capabilities
External dependencies and APIs are validated as available
Performance requirements are achievable with proposed architecture
Deployment environment is accessible and properly sized

subsection.name: 5.2 Implementation Risk Assessment
subsection.i: High-risk technical areas identified and addressed early
Complex integrations have fallback approaches
New technology adoption is justified and scoped appropriately
Data migration or legacy system impacts considered
Testing approach covers critical functionality and NFRs

section.name: 6. Overall PRD Completeness
section.desc: Final validation that PRD provides sufficient guidance
section.llm: Could an architect and development team proceed confidently with this PRD?

subsection.name: 6.1 Goal-to-Implementation Alignment
subsection.i: Project goals are clearly reflected in epic outcomes
User journeys are fully supported by story implementations
Success metrics are achievable through delivered functionality
Background context supports all requirements and scope decisions
Out of scope items prevent obvious feature creep

subsection.name: 6.2 Handoff Readiness
subsection.i: Technical requirements provide clear direction for architect
UI design goals (if present) give sufficient UX guidance
User journeys inform both architecture and UX decisions
Epic/story structure enables agile development approach
Next steps section provides clear handoff instructions

report.overall-status: Calculate percentage of requirements covered by epics/stories
report.epic-story-quality: Ready for Development | Needs Refinement | Major Issues
report.critical-gaps: List any blocking issues or missing coverage
report.bloat-risks: Identify potential scope creep or over-engineering
report.recommendations: Specific actions to improve coverage and focus
